title: 114_s2238
content:
The "Keep It in the Ground Act of 2015" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings and a statement of policy. Congress finds that global temperatures have increased by 0.9 degrees Celsius from 1880 to 2014, primarily due to human activities like burning fossil fuels. Greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise, leading to a warming trend with significant impacts on the economy and environment. To avoid exceeding a 2-degree Celsius increase, 80 percent of carbon from fossil fuel reserves must be kept in the ground. To prevent exceeding a 2-degree Celsius warming, 80 percent of carbon from proven fossil fuel reserves must be kept in the ground. Ending new leases for fossil fuels on Federal land will prevent the release of 90 percent of potential emissions. Federal land and waters should be managed to avoid dangerous climate impacts and promote a transition to a clean energy economy by keeping fossil fuels in the ground. The Federal Government should not issue any new leases or renew existing ones. To benefit the people of the United States, no new leases or renewals for coal, oil, or natural gas on Federal land or waters will be issued. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Extend - extending a lease under the Mineral Leasing Act beyond the existing term.
Nonproducing lease - a lease where no fossil fuel has been extracted for commercial use.
Reinstate - reinstating a lease after a violation that led to suspension or cancellation.
Renew - renewing a lease for a term not longer than the maximum renewal term.
Secretary - the Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 4. STOPPING NEW OFFSHORE OIL AND GAS LEASES IN THE GULF OF MEXICO AND THE PACIFIC, ATLANTIC, AND ARCTIC OCEANS. Prohibition on new oil and gas leasing on the Outer Continental Shelf, including definitions for terms like extend, nonproducing lease, and reinstate. The Act prohibits new oil and gas leasing on the Outer Continental Shelf, including definitions for terms like renew, reinstate, and nonproducing lease. The Secretary of the Interior is restricted from issuing new leases or authorizations for exploration in specific ocean areas. The Act prohibits new oil and gas leasing on the Outer Continental Shelf, including canceling existing leases in specified areas within 60 days of enactment. SEC. 5 of the Act prohibits new leases for coal, oil, tar sands, fracked gas, and oil shale on federal land. It also restricts renewing or extending nonproducing leases for fossil fuels. The Secretary may exempt provisions of the Act for a lease in case of imminent national security threat, with the exemption lasting as long as the threat persists. Nonproducing leases can be renewed if signed before the Act's enactment and if enforcing the Act may lead to a court case. The Act allows for exemptions in cases of national security threats, with exemptions lasting as long as the threat persists. Renewals of nonproducing leases must be for the shortest time possible to comply with the lease terms. SEC. 7. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or its amendments is deemed invalid or unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and its amendments will not be affected.
